title: 110_hr5461
content: The Act may be cited as the "White House Conference on Children and Youth in 2010 Act". The Congress finds that in 2005, there were over 3,000,000 reports of child abuse and neglect, with only 60% of substantiated cases receiving follow-up services. Nearly 900,000 cases of child abuse and neglect are reported each year, with neglect being the most common type. Additionally, almost 500,000 children were in foster care in 2004, and around 51,000 children are adopted from foster care annually. While 51,000 children are adopted from the foster care system each year, more than 117,000 children are waiting to be adopted. Approximately 22,000 youth leave the foster care system annually due to aging out. The child welfare system involves various entities such as governments, agencies, caseworkers, and advocates. Certain populations like Native Americans and African-Americans are over-represented in the system. Additionally, there is a growing number of children being raised by grandparents. The child welfare system recognizes kinship care as a permanency option through the Adoption and Safe Families Act of 1997. State courts play a crucial role in making decisions for children in the system, including child abuse cases, parental rights termination, and placement options. The system's primary mission cannot be fully achieved without the courts being an integral part of a statewide care and protection system. The Congress policy emphasizes collaboration between the Government and States to develop plans for child welfare systems, focusing on enhancing the well-being of children and families. Federal, State, and local programs should align with these goals. Federal, State, and local programs should aim to reduce child abuse and neglect, decrease the number of children in foster care, and increase permanent placements through family reunification, kinship placement, and adoption. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION OF THE CONFERENCE. The President is authorized to call a White House Conference on Children and Youth in 2010 to address child welfare systems and develop recommendations for improvement. The Secretary will plan and conduct the Conference in collaboration with other federal entities to identify issues related to child abuse and neglect. The White House Conference on Children and Youth in 2010 aims to address child welfare systems and develop recommendations for improvement. These recommendations include strengthening research-based best practices to prevent child abuse and neglect, increasing placement permanency for children removed from their homes, promoting the role of State family courts, and reducing the number of children in out-of-home care and the overrepresentation of certain populations in the child welfare system. The White House Conference on Children and Youth in 2010 aims to address child welfare systems by examining the role of the Government in building an equal partnership and developing specific recommendations for State-level action to improve the well-being of children in the system. It also includes reviewing previous recommendations regarding child welfare. The policy committee is established. The Policy Committee is established with 17 members selected by the President and House of Representatives, including individuals with experience in child welfare. The Policy Committee consists of 17 members chosen by the President and House of Representatives, with two members each selected by the majority and minority leaders of the House and Senate. The committee acts by majority vote. The Policy Committee, consisting of 17 members chosen by the President and House of Representatives, is chaired by the President's selection. The committee's duties include making recommendations to the Secretary for the timely convening of the Conference and submitting a proposed agenda within 90 days of its first meeting. The Policy Committee, chaired by the President's selection, must convene a Conference within 90 days of its first meeting. It will recommend delegates, establish delegate selection procedures, and create advisory committees for professionals and families in the child welfare system. SEC. 5. CONFERENCE DELEGATES. The Secretary will gather delegates from various backgrounds in child welfare and the courts, including directors of child welfare systems, members of judicial systems, elected officials, advocates, guardians, experts, families, children, and the general public. SEC. 6. CONFERENCE ADMINISTRATION. The Secretary shall request cooperation from other Federal entities, provide assistance to State child welfare systems, and prepare an agenda for the Conference reflecting major child welfare issues. The Secretary is responsible for addressing major child welfare issues, providing background materials for conference delegates, and hiring additional personnel as needed. This includes ensuring broad participation in conferences. The Secretary is responsible for addressing child welfare issues and ensuring broad participation in conferences, including those focused on Native Americans to identify and propose solutions for adverse conditions affecting their children in the child welfare system. The agenda for the Conference will include discussions on delivering services to Native American families at risk of entering the child welfare system. The agenda for the Conference must be published in the Federal Register at least 180 days before the Conference and open for public comment for 60 days. The final agenda, taking into account public comments, must be published and sent to state chief executive officers within 30 days after the public comment period. Personnel employed must be balanced in terms of viewpoints and appointed without consideration of political affiliation or partisan activities. Before the Conference is convened, the Secretary must ensure that current statistical data and information on children's well-being in the United States, as well as information to evaluate Federal programs, are readily available. Before the Conference, the Secretary ensures that current statistical data and information on children's well-being in the United States, as well as data to evaluate Federal programs, are available to delegates in advance. SEC. 7. REPORT OF THE CONFERENCE. The Secretary shall prepare a proposed report on the results of the Conference, including a statement of national policy on State child welfare systems and recommendations for implementation. The report will be published in the Federal Register and sent to state chief executive officers within 60 days. After reviewing the report, states must submit their views on the recommendations within 180 days. A final report must be submitted within 90 days of receiving state views. The Secretary shall prepare a final report of the Conference within 90 days, including the views and findings of state chief executive officers. The report will contain recommendations for administrative action and necessary legislation, to be published in the Federal Register and transmitted to the President and Congress. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services, and "State" includes various regions. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $10,000,000 is authorized for this Act. SEC. 10. LIMITATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. New spending authority is subject to appropriations Acts.
